Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Risk Area Residents' Response to Hurricane Harvey

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Evacuation is a critical component in a community's disaster preparedness plan. The challenge is that lives can be lost during evacuations too. Such loss of life is especially likely in a hurricane with a late-changing track striking a major urban area because household evacuation preparation often places many evacuees on the road at the same time. Despite the best transportation planning models, major traffic jams commonly occur in the surge zone. This research will improve our understanding of the time it takes for households to receive warnings, prepare to evacuate, and choose their evacuation routes and destinations. It will also expand our knowledge of the role of demographic and experiential characteristics of these households to predict warning reception, evacuation preparation, and route/destination choice.

This project will advance the scientific understanding of household hurricane evacuations by conducting a survey of 800 randomly selected households in Corpus Christi Texas. This survey has six specific objectives: 1) collect data on hurricane warning dissemination times, 2) collect data on household evacuation preparation times, 3) collect data on household evacuation logistics (e.g., route choices, destination choices, evacuation durations, and evacuation costs), 4) assess the ability of demographic, experiential, and risk perception data to predict evacuation departure times and evacuation logistics, 5) collect data on risk area occupants' observations of graphic displays of hurricane tracks, hurricane impacts, and evacuation guidance, and 6) assess the ability of demographic, experiential, and graphic displays to predict risk perception, evacuation decisions, and evacuation departure times. Understanding how long it takes for individuals to decide to evacuate and to actually evacuate is a critical and poorly understood part of evacuation models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A recent review of research of hurricane evacuation time estimate components identified substantial uncertainties in estimates of warning diffusion and household mobilization. This study found that data on warning diffusion in hurricanes is extremely sparse and the empirical base for estimating household mobilization times, though marginally stronger, is also problematic. Specifically, researchers have found inconsistent results when assessing mobilization time through items addressing a) in-home task performance times (e.g., time spent installing shutters), b) evacuation departure delay times (i.e., the difference between the evacuation decision time and evacuation departure time), and c) pre-evacuation tour durations (i.e., the time spent during within-town trips to make purchases such as gas food, and medications). The Hurricane Harvey evacuation provided an opportunity to collect a unique set of data to address these evacuation time components, as well as hurricane evacuees’ evacuation logistics—including their route choices, destination choices, evacuation durations, and evacuation costs. 

The Hurricane Harvey survey, which was conducted in collaboration between this NSF grant and a US Army Corps of Engineers contract, was directed to households in eight Texas counties that varied in their evacuation rates—Aransas (85%), Calhoun (69%), Jackson (54%), Matagorda (72%), Nueces (42%), Refugio (49%), San Patricio (77%), and Victoria (45%). Consistent with previous research, the survey’s preliminary results show that the number of vehicles taken per household ranged from 1.3 in one county to 1.5 in six of the counties. Only 9% of the respondents evacuated using some means of transportation other than their own personal vehicle and only 11% required special medical assistance when evacuating. Despite the consistency in the number of vehicles taken, the average vehicle occupancy ranged from 1.6 to 2.4, suggesting that households generally tried to travel together by evacuating in a single vehicle whenever feasible. This conclusion is supported by the finding that 78-95 percent of the households evacuated all members at the same time. In confirmation of previous findings, many more households left the day before landfall than on the day of landfall. Unexpectedly, however, many households left 2-4 days before landfall. For all departure days, evacuation departures were most common in the late morning and early afternoon and least common in the overnight hours. 

Additional analyses of the data from this survey are examining the frequency of local trips to buy gas, water, food, and medicine; get money; and pick up other riders. The analyses are also examining the evacuation routes used and the reasons for choosing these routes, as well as the accommodations chosen (peer’s home, commercial facility, public shelter) and whether any prior arrangements were made for these accommodations before evacuating. All of these analyses are examining the extent to which different aspects of evacuation timing and evacuation logistics are systematically related to evacuees’ demographic characteristics. This information will be extremely useful in refining state and local emergency managers’ hurricane evacuation plans for risk, transit, and host counties.
